complexityChecks.description: When supported by the stack, run cyclomatic complexity or similar metrics in CI as a warning-only check initially.

qualityGatePolicy.description: New quality checks should warn on existing code and fail CI only for violations introduced in new or changed code, to reduce friction on legacy codebases.

migrationGuide.title: Establish Local Safety Nets First
migrationGuide.description: Start by adding pre-commit hooks and core formatting/linting so developers get fast feedback without touching CI.
migrationGuide.notes: Keep hooks fast and focused on changed files to avoid slowing down day-to-day work.

migrationGuide.title: Mirror Local Checks in CI (Soft-Fail on Legacy)
migrationGuide.description: Introduce CI quality gates that mirror local checks, but treat existing violations as warnings wherever possible.
migrationGuide.notes: Use diff-based tools or baselines so only new violations break builds; legacy issues remain visible but non-blocking.

migrationGuide.title: Add Type Safety, Coverage, and Dependency Security
migrationGuide.description: Enable type-checking, coverage thresholds, and dependency/vulnerability scanning with gradual enforcement.
migrationGuide.notes: Pin tool and runtime versions in CI and containers to avoid flaky differences across environments.

migrationGuide.title: Layer in Docs, Governance, and Recommended Checks
migrationGuide.description: Add documentation standards, governance files, integration testing, performance baselines, complexity analysis, accessibility auditing, and (optionally) ML-specific practices for data-heavy Python repos.
migrationGuide.notes: Tackle recommended items in order of business value; backend-only repos can skip web-focused checks like accessibility. For AI/ML-heavy Python teams, consider extending containerization with data versioning (DVC) and unit tests with data quality checks (e.g., Great Expectations) as part of this step.

core.label: Git and Docker Ignore Files
core.description: Maintain proper .gitignore and .dockerignore files to prevent committing secrets, build artifacts, or unnecessary files.

typescript-js.notes: Use the official github/gitignore Node template as a base and add .env*, node_modules, dist/, coverage/, *.log, npm-debug.log*, etc. .dockerignore must exclude node_modules, .git, and local build output.
typescript-js.verification: .gitignore must exist; .dockerignore is recommended when containerizing or using Docker workflows.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Use the official github/gitignore VisualStudio/.NET template. .dockerignore must exclude bin/, obj/, .vs/, *.user, and similar local/build artifacts.
csharp-dotnet.verification: .gitignore must exist; .dockerignore is recommended when containerizing or using Docker workflows.

python.notes: Use the official github/gitignore Python template. Include **pycache**, .venv/, .pytest_cache, .env, and similar local-only files. .dockerignore must exclude .git, virtual environments, and caches.
python.verification: .gitignore must exist; .dockerignore is recommended when containerizing or using Docker workflows.

core.label: Linting
core.description: Run static code linting to enforce consistency and catch common issues early.

typescript-js.notes: Treat new lint errors as CI failures; keep existing issues as warnings until addressed.
typescript-js.verification: Presence of eslint.config.js (or any .eslintrc* file) indicates linting is enforced for the repository.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Enable analyzers or style rules for the solution and review warnings regularly; enforce stricter rules on new code.
csharp-dotnet.verification: .editorconfig must exist to drive the .NET formatting and analysis tooling.

python.notes: Configure a primary linter (such as ruff) and keep rules focused on catching real issues without overwhelming developers.
python.verification: pyproject.toml (or ruff.toml / .flake8) signals that linting tools are configured for the repository.

core.label: Unit Test Runner
core.description: Provide a deterministic unit test framework with a single command to run all tests.

typescript-js.notes: Keep unit tests fast and deterministic; move slow or flaky tests into integration or E2E suites.
typescript-js.verification: Test framework configuration is present; test script is defined in package.json.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Group unit tests into dedicated test projects and keep them independent from external services.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Test projects are present in the solution; test configuration is defined.

python.notes: Organize unit tests under a tests/ directory and avoid real network or database calls in this layer.
python.verification: Test framework configuration is present; tests/ directory or pytest configuration exists.

core.label: Containerization (Docker / Docker Compose)
core.description: Provide a Dockerfile and, if applicable, a docker-compose file for local dev and CI parity.

typescript-js.notes: Use multi-stage builds and pin Node.js and base image versions in the Dockerfile to match CI (e.g., node:22-alpine).
typescript-js.verification: Dockerfile must be present; docker-compose.yml is optional and indicates orchestration usage.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Use multi-stage builds for .NET publish output and pin the SDK/runtime image versions to match CI.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Dockerfile must be present; docker-compose.yml is optional and indicates orchestration usage.

python.notes: Choose a slim Python base image, pin the version, and clearly document how to start the service in a container.
python.verification: Dockerfile must be present; docker-compose.yml is optional and indicates orchestration usage.

core.label: Semantic Versioning
core.description: Use MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH versioning with clear rules and automated changelog generation based on commit history.

typescript-js.notes: Automate version bumping and changelog generation from Conventional Commits using semantic-release or standard-version. Configure CI to automatically bump package.json version, generate/update CHANGELOG.md, create git tags, and publish release artifacts. Protect release branches and ensure release tooling only runs there.
typescript-js.verification: Check that the version field follows SemVer, and trigger the configured release workflow (for example, a dry run of semantic-release or standard-version) to confirm it automatically generates the expected next version, updates package.json, and creates/updates CHANGELOG.md with commit-based entries.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Use GitVersion to automatically compute SemVer from git history and feed it into assembly/package versions. Configure CI to auto-generate or update CHANGELOG.md from commit messages and git tags. Integrate with release pipeline to automatically version assemblies, NuGet packages, and create release notes.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Check that versioning is driven by a SemVer-aware tool (for example, GitVersion) and verify that running the release/versioning step locally or in CI automatically produces the expected version metadata, updates project files, and generates changelog entries from commit history.

python.notes: Automate version bumping and changelog generation using setuptools_scm (git-tag based) or bumpversion with towncrier for changelog fragments. Configure CI to automatically update version in pyproject.toml, generate/update CHANGELOG.md from commit messages or changelog fragments, and create git tags. Maintain a single source of truth for versioning.
python.verification: Check that the package version in pyproject or setup configuration follows SemVer and verify that the configured tool (for example, setuptools_scm or bumpversion) automatically computes or bumps the version and generates changelog entries from commit history or fragments.

core.label: Commit Linting
core.description: Enforce structured commit messages such as Conventional Commits.

typescript-js.notes: Enforce commit message format via commit-msg hooks (e.g., Husky) before CI.
typescript-js.verification: Create a test commit using the documented convention and ensure the commit message passes the configured commit linting or wizard (for example, commitlint or commitizen).

csharp-dotnet.notes: Document your commit convention and wire up a helper tool so contributors can easily follow it.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Create a test commit following the documented commit convention and confirm that any configured commit message checks (local hooks or CI) accept the message.

python.notes: Standardize commit messages using commitizen or a similar helper and document the required types and scopes.
python.verification: Use the configured commit helper (for example, commitizen) or hooks to create a test commit and confirm that non-conforming messages are rejected while valid ones are accepted.

core.label: Unit Test Reporter / Coverage
core.description: Generate readable unit test and coverage reports and enforce a minimum coverage threshold (around 80%) for new or changed code.

typescript-js.notes: Collect coverage in lcov or similar format; use diff coverage so legacy gaps are visible but non-blocking.
typescript-js.verification: Run the unit tests with coverage enabled and confirm that a coverage report is produced and that the configured threshold (around 80%) is enforced for new changes.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Enable coverage collection for test projects and publish reports in a human-friendly format from CI.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Run the test suite with coverage enabled (for example, using coverlet or a similar tool) and verify that coverage reports are generated and used in CI to monitor thresholds.

python.notes: Configure coverage reporting for your test suite and surface summary metrics in CI.
python.verification: Run the unit tests with coverage (for example, pytest with pytest-cov) and confirm that coverage reports are generated and referenced in CI to enforce or track thresholds.

core.label: CI Quality Gates
core.description: Single CI pipeline that runs linting, formatting, type checking, tests, coverage, build, and containerization.

typescript-js.notes: Expose a single npm script (e.g., `npm run ci`) that mirrors the CI pipeline so contributors can reproduce failures locally.
typescript-js.verification: Open the CI configuration and verify there is a job or stage that runs linting, type checking, tests, build, and any required container checks before merging to main.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Ensure CI runs analyzers, tests, build, and packaging or container checks before changes can be merged.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Open the CI configuration and verify there is a job or stage that runs analyzers, tests, build, and any required packaging or container checks before merging to main.

python.notes: Ensure CI runs linting, type checking (if used), tests, and packaging or container checks for Python services before merging.
python.verification: Open the CI configuration and verify there is a job or stage that runs linting, type checking (if used), tests, and any packaging or container checks before merging to main.

core.label: Code Formatter
core.description: Automatic code formatting to maintain a consistent style across all contributors.

typescript-js.notes: Run Prettier in check mode in CI; auto-fix locally via pre-commit hooks or editor integration.
typescript-js.verification: Run the formatter in check mode (for example, `npm run format:check`) and confirm it reports clean formatting on committed code and auto-fixes as expected locally.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Use .editorconfig and dotnet-format to keep C# style consistent across contributors.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Run the configured formatter or code style enforcement (for example, `dotnet format`) and confirm that code in the repository conforms to the defined rules.

python.notes: Use black (or an equivalent opinionated formatter) and treat its output as the single source of truth for code style.
python.verification: Run the configured formatter (for example, `black .` or `black --check .`) and confirm it reports clean formatting on committed code and auto-fixes as expected locally.

core.label: Pre-Commit Hooks
core.description: Use git hooks to run linting, formatting, tests, and commit linting before changes are committed.

typescript-js.notes: Run ESLint and Prettier on staged files and enforce commit message format via commit-msg hooks.
typescript-js.verification: Inspect the pre-commit and commit-msg hooks (for example, files under .husky or other hook tooling) and confirm they run linting/formatting and commit linting on staged changes.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Configure Lefthook or similar to run formatting and basic checks on staged files before commits.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Inspect the hook configuration (for example, Lefthook or similar) and confirm it runs at least formatting and basic checks on staged changes before commits or pushes.

python.notes: Use pre-commit to run ruff, black, and optionally mypy on staged files before committing.
python.verification: Inspect .pre-commit-config.yaml and confirm that hooks for linting, formatting, and optionally type checking are enabled and run on changed files before commits.

core.label: Type Checking
core.description: Use static type checking to catch errors before runtime and enforce strictness on new code.

typescript-js.notes: Enable strict mode ('strict': true) and treat type-check failures as CI failures for new code; gradually expand strictness into legacy modules.
typescript-js.verification: Presence of tsconfig.json indicates type-checking is configured for the repository.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Enable nullable reference types and relevant analyzers to catch type and nullability issues at compile time. C# project files (*.csproj) indicate the presence of projects that can be type-checked.
csharp-dotnet.verification: .editorconfig must exist; Directory.Build.props is optional for shared build configuration.

python.notes: Adopt gradual typing with type hints and mypy, focusing first on critical modules and new code paths.
python.verification: pyproject.toml (or mypy.ini) signals that mypy configuration is available for the repository.

core.label: Dependency Management & Vulnerability Scanning
core.description: Lock dependencies and scan regularly for known vulnerabilities; fail CI on newly introduced high-severity issues.

typescript-js.notes: Require a lockfile for reproducible installs and pin Node.js/tooling versions; block merges on new high-severity vulnerabilities.
typescript-js.verification: Dependency lockfile is present; security scanning is configured in CI or project tooling.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Enable package lock files and use vulnerability scanning to track and remediate high-risk dependencies.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Dependency lockfile or package reference is present; security scanning is configured.

python.notes: Pin dependency versions and routinely scan for vulnerabilities, prioritizing fixes for critical and high-severity issues.
python.verification: Dependency lockfile is present; security scanning is configured in CI or project tooling.

core.label: Runtime Version Specification
core.description: Specify required runtime/engine versions in package manifests to ensure environment stability and prevent version-related issues across development teams.

typescript-js.notes: Specify the 'engines' field in package.json to define the required Node.js version (e.g., "engines": { "node": ">=18.0.0" }). This helps prevent environment-related bugs and ensures all developers use compatible Node.js versions.
typescript-js.verification: package.json must contain an 'engines' field specifying the required Node.js version.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Specify TargetFramework in .csproj files (e.g., <TargetFramework>net8.0</TargetFramework>) and optionally use global.json to pin the SDK version (e.g., { "sdk": { "version": "8.0.100" } }) for consistent builds across the team.
csharp-dotnet.verification: .csproj files must specify TargetFramework; global.json is recommended to pin SDK version.

python.notes: Specify python_requires in pyproject.toml (e.g., requires-python = ">=3.9") or setup.py (e.g., python_requires='>=3.9'). Consider adding .python-version for pyenv users to automatically switch to the correct Python version.
python.verification: pyproject.toml or setup.py must specify python_requires; .python-version is recommended for local development.

core.label: Documentation Standards
core.description: Maintain a comprehensive README and, where applicable, auto-generated API docs to support onboarding and maintainability.

typescript-js.notes: README should describe setup, scripts, and architecture; generate API docs from TypeScript types and JSDoc where helpful.
typescript-js.verification: README.md is present in the repository root; docs/ directory or documentation tooling configuration exists if applicable.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Keep README and API docs in sync with the solution structure and public surface area.
csharp-dotnet.verification: README.md is present in the repository root; docs/ directory or DocFX configuration exists if applicable.

python.notes: Ensure README explains environment setup and core commands, and generate API docs from docstrings where appropriate.
python.verification: README.md is present in the repository root; docs/ directory or documentation tooling configuration exists if applicable.

core.label: Repository Governance
core.description: Include standard governance files (LICENSE, CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md, CONTRIBUTING.md), branch protection rules, and review standards to define legal, ethical, and workflow expectations.

typescript-js.notes: Use an SPDX license identifier in package.json and describe review expectations, tests, and docs requirements in CONTRIBUTING.md.
typescript-js.verification: LICENSE file is present in the repository root; CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md and CONTRIBUTING.md are present for contribution guidance.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Document contribution expectations and ensure legal and code-of-conduct policies are easy to find.
csharp-dotnet.verification: LICENSE file is present in the repository root; CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md and CONTRIBUTING.md are present for contribution guidance.

python.notes: Spell out contributor responsibilities for tests, documentation, and review so expectations are clear for Python-focused teams.
python.verification: LICENSE file is present in the repository root; CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md and CONTRIBUTING.md are present for contribution guidance.

recommended.label: Integration Testing
recommended.description: Test how components interact with each other and external systems, running after unit tests with more relaxed coverage thresholds.

typescript-js.notes: Use Supertest for HTTP APIs and Playwright or similar tools for end-to-end flows; keep integration suites slower but reliable.
typescript-js.verification: Confirm there is a separate integration or end-to-end test command or configuration and run it to verify that cross-component flows behave as expected.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Create dedicated integration test projects that exercise real infrastructure or service boundaries where appropriate.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Confirm there is a test project or configuration dedicated to integration or API tests and run it to verify external or cross-service interactions behave as expected.

python.notes: Separate integration tests from unit tests, using fixtures to handle databases, services, or other external systems.
python.verification: Confirm there is a separate integration or API test suite (for example, a dedicated tests/integration directory) and run it to verify interactions with databases, services, or external systems.

recommended.label: Performance Baselines
recommended.description: Establish performance baselines and monitor for regressions using lightweight benchmarks or audits in CI.

typescript-js.notes: Run Lighthouse CI for web apps and basic Node benchmarks on critical endpoints; schedule runs or limit to key branches to keep CI fast.
typescript-js.verification: Identify and run the configured performance or Lighthouse-style checks and verify that key metrics are captured and compared to documented baselines.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Use BenchmarkDotNet or similar to track performance of critical methods or endpoints over time.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Identify and run the configured performance or benchmarking suite (for example, BenchmarkDotNet) and review the output to ensure it is tracked against historical or target values.

python.notes: Use simple benchmarks or profiling runs to characterize bottlenecks and watch for regressions in critical workflows.
python.verification: Identify and run the configured performance checks or benchmarks (for example, pytest-benchmark or cProfile-based scripts) and confirm that their results are recorded and compared over time.

recommended.label: Complexity Analysis
recommended.description: Measure cyclomatic complexity or similar metrics to keep code maintainable, starting as a warning-only check.

typescript-js.notes: Warn on overly complex functions and methods; fail CI only when new or modified code exceeds thresholds.
typescript-js.verification: Run the configured complexity tooling or rules (for example, ESLint complexity rules or Sonar analysis) and review any hot spots, ensuring new code does not exceed agreed thresholds.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Use code metrics or Sonar analysis to flag overly complex methods and refactor them over time.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Run the configured code metrics or Sonar analysis and review complexity reports for key modules, ensuring that new or changed code stays within acceptable limits.

python.notes: Use radon or similar tools to track complexity of Python functions and keep new code within acceptable limits.
python.verification: Run the configured complexity tool (for example, radon) on the codebase and review the report to ensure new or heavily changed functions are not excessively complex.

recommended.label: Accessibility Auditing
recommended.description: Run accessibility checks on web-facing components to detect critical issues and improve inclusive UX.

typescript-js.notes: Run accessibility checks against key pages or components in CI; fail on critical violations while treating minor issues as warnings initially.
typescript-js.verification: For web-facing apps, run the configured accessibility tooling (for example, axe, pa11y, or Lighthouse accessibility audits) against key pages and confirm that critical issues are resolved.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Apply accessibility tooling to ASP.NET or Blazor front-ends and review issues alongside functional testing.
csharp-dotnet.verification: For web-facing apps, run the configured accessibility checks or tools against your main UI endpoints and confirm that blocking accessibility issues are addressed.

python.notes: Use headless browser-based tools to scan Python-backed web UIs for accessibility issues on high-traffic routes.
python.verification: For Python-backed web UIs, run the configured accessibility tooling (for example, pa11y or axe via a headless browser) against key routes and verify that critical issues are fixed or tracked.

optionalEnhancements.label: Observability (Logging & Error Handling)
optionalEnhancements.description: Standardize error handling and structured logging to make debugging and production monitoring easier.

typescript-js.notes: Adopt structured JSON logging with correlation IDs and send logs to a centralized sink in production.
typescript-js.verification: Confirm that a structured logging library (such as Winston or Pino) is configured to emit JSON or key-value logs and that error handling routes important failures through this logger.

csharp-dotnet.notes: Configure structured logging for your .NET services and ensure exceptions and key events are logged with useful context.
csharp-dotnet.verification: Confirm that a structured logging library (such as Serilog or NLog) is configured with an agreed sink and format, and that the application logs meaningful context for errors and key events.

python.notes: Use structured logging for Python services and ensure critical paths record enough context to debug issues after the fact.
python.verification: Confirm that a structured logging setup (such as structlog or configured logging with JSON formatting) is in place and that critical paths log enough information to debug failures in production.
